Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.

I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Christopher W. Beltz  Chris Beltz
Instructor: Christopher W. Beltz  Christopher Beltz
Instructor: Christopher W. Beltz  Beltz, Christopher

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Christopher W. Beltz  Chris did a great job of leading discussions on interesting course readings. If he was the one who picked and organized the readings, this was also to his credit, as they were very interesting. He gave an engaging, interesting lecture that proved his ability to hold a classroom. I would really like to study with him more in the future.
Instructor: Christopher W. Beltz  Chris was engaged, accessible, and informative.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is an excellent course. A fascinating mix of information about plants, animals, soils, climate, and human disturbances within America's drylands.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I enjoyed both the lectures and the discussions about discrete articles. I really appreciated that the readings were short and to the point. I read everything assigned for this class because the amount of material assigned for each class was so reasonable. When faculty over-assign reading, it becomes impossible to do all of it when things get busy, and the result is that I will often do none of it for lack of any basis upon which to pick and choose. For this class, the readings were so well chosen, interesting, and reasonable in length that it was a pleasure to do all of them.
This is a great course for anyone interested in the American West. The material situates Western geography and land use in a fascinating ecological context.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It was great in all respects. But a fieldtrip would be fun--and interesting!
A little more clarity on deadlines and expectations would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The discussions were relevant to the lecture material.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is a perfect fit for my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in North American drylands.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I really appreciated that this course was part of the curriculum. There are all too few courses at FES that focus on particular ecosystems. I wish there were many more. They should be modeled after this one.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! And beg for more courses modeled on the same theory that FES students should emerge with in-depth knowledge of significant ecosystems and the forces that threaten them.
I highly recommend this course as a great introduction to both land use issues and ecology of the American West.
An excellent course no matter one's familiarity with North American drylands.
